message:
"Git" gurus, could you please help me in something

As far as I know, Git access could be manipulated through server user/group authentication. but is there is any way that I can use another access authentication regardless the OS server authentication?

data.message:
Have you checked what Stash can do?

https://www.atlassian.com/software/stash

Mohamed Meligy I wish :D . I am in a company that supports open source; to the core. but it would be very good for me  though :)

I think I am gonna use gitolite, the free un-user-friendly solution ;)

Git doesn't use os authen. It uses any mean you provide 
Gitolite is a headace after I used it , limited and probably you might want t o use cgit too , too much work
But you don't have to go through the hassle of doing everything 
Try gitlab : gitlab.com
Git management using single host os account , smart issue tracking , nice GUI , ...
Even it has os specific packages rpm, deb , so the installation will be straight forward

i came through it, but I didn't figure how the developers will commit through eclipse or through its GUI. Committing through command line is a bigger headache. that is why I want to use gitolite over gitlab or Gitblit

Imagine for ftp :
Users can use command line tool called , ftp
Or use GUI called filezilla to do the very same thing 
As long as both command line and GUI tool understand the same protocol , both will do the same thing 

Netbeans and other IDEs have libraries enables them to fetch , pull push to git server just like the command line tool 

And both , as long as they support git they will use the authen method you configured your git server to it , SSH or HTTP or whatever 

I think you should try make your own github repo and try yourself before taking the decision

Actually Gitlab is awesome. Thanks Araby for mentioning (I forgot all about it although a colleague blogged about it a few years ago).

It's just a virtual machine that contains git and preinstalled web UI to manage it.

The nature of the git server doesn't dictate how the developers commit/push. Even if it uses SSH, there are UI clients on Windows and Mac (GitExtensions comes with putty integrated by default and Source Tree has it built in its own UI, Eclipse sure can do something too)
what i like about gitlab, it isn't just an admin tool for Git repos . it is much more (Y)
